												Cliffs of Dover is an excellent World War 2 flight simulator, recreating what it is like to be a British or German combat pilot during the Summer of 1940. HOWEVER, it is excellent only if you use the Team Fusion patch. Let me make that clear. Cliffs of Dover should have been an excellent product from the first. Its vision and the designed scope of improvement over other WW2 flight sims was, and still is, truly next generation. However, the sim was a commercial flop - for a variety of reasons. More than anything, the effect its release had on the flight simming community was to generate at first epic anger, and later, epic sighs of disapointment. We all had high hopes, but they were decisively dashed after the initial boot-up of what has become known as IL-2 CloD. Frame rates when the sim was first released were slide-show poor, stability was enough to make Job tear his hair, and menu navigation was inexplicably difficult. These and a myriad of other major issues kept anyone from feeling they got their money's worth. Most who had purchased Cliffs of Dover, eagerly expecting the best WW2 sim experience possible, quickly shelved it after vigorously (and justly) lambasting the developers online. The issues with which this product first shipped are unacceptable for any entertainment product if it is going to succeed. And, therefore due to the quality, or lack of it, succeed IL-2 Cliffs of Dover did not. The vision was there, the scope was there, the basics were there - but the execution left all the positives absolutely irrelevant.Now fast forward in time to the present. Over the years since release, a series of patches from the developers have addressed many issues in the software, partly to silence their critics, but also in an effort to salvage their reputation for further software development. The most recent developer's patch, however, came with a statement: No More Work Will Be Done. Although the official patches fixed many issues, serious flaws still remained unaddressed. Seeing that CloD had been abandoned by the developers, a small group of historically-minded flight sim enthusiasts took it upon themselves to fix the glitches that remain, adding content as well as restored functionality. The result has been, literally, a game-changer. Frame rates are at 60FPS on modern machines, flight modeling is impressive, software stability is great, and the single player campaigns have even been re-written. Multiplayer is fantastic. 50 to 100 human pilots routinely fly together, in one server, over the English channel and French and English countrysides, re-enacting the dramatic days before, during, and after the Battle of Britain. You can find your aerial combat fix nearly any day or night on the ATAG (TF) multiplayer server. Team Fusion continues to poll the community for needed changes, and to add more content and bugfixes regularly. Their forum, and their patches, can be found at: http://theairtacticalassaultgroup.com/forum/forumdisplay.php?f=91I highly recommend IL-2 CloD if you are a serious WW2 flight sim enthusiast. To date, it has the highest degree of period engine and flight modelling that a complete WW2 flight simulation product  has delivered. You will feel as if you are piloting a piston-powered, 1200 horsepower, state of the art (for 1940) aircraft into realistic and deadly combat using nothing but a compass, high-power guns, crosshairs gunsight, and your wits. It is not an easy sim. It is a realistic one. If that is what you want, you have found it. Just make sure you use the TF additions. -Venturi

												I have been flying Cliffs of Dover for well over 400 hours now and I cannot recommend it enough. If you like World War 2 history and have an interest in flight simulators, look no further: this is the game you’ve been waiting for. You will relive the Battle of Britain like you have never seen it before. You will find yourself crammed into a claustrophobic cockpit and fight for either the Royal Air Force, the Luftwaffe or the Regia Aeronautica Italiana. If you are an aviation buff, you will be pleased to find an impressive selection of aircraft used during the battle, even less known aircraft like the Boulton-Paul Defiant, the Supermarine Walrus, the Short Sunderland, the Dornier Do-17 or the Vickers Wellington. Of course, not all of these aircraft are flyable yet but the iconic planes like the Spitfire, Bf.109, Hurricane, G.50, Blenheim IV, Ju-88, He-111 and Br.20 can be flown. You can fly online with up to 100 people, which makes for very impressive battles with friends and foes.The story of Il-2 Cliffs of Dover is a long and complicated one. When Ubisoft and 1C Game Studios dropped support for the game, a merry band of volunteers decided to create a free mod in order to fix the many issues Cliffs of Dover had back in the years 2011 to 2013. They became known as Team Fusion, and they keep modding CloD to this day and are slowly expanding the game to a whole new level. Sound mods, graphical fixes, performance improvement, flight model adjustment, new flyable aircraft, additional war theaters… these guys transformed this sim from the buggy-and-barely-playable-piece-of-junk mentioned in early reviews to what we have today. The difference between pre-mod and after-mod is mindblowing and it is the only way to play this game, trust me.The strength of the game is that it is a happy medium between the complexity of a study sim like DCS and the accessibility of an arcade sim like War Thunder. You can jump into a cockpit and fly like you’re really there. You need to keep your engine temperatures (oil and water radiator) in check by maintaining proper RPM and manifold pressure settings (which are controlled by prop pitch and throttle controls) that should come with any cheap joystick you can buy on the market. Just like in real life, your aircraft will be prone to stall, spin and attempt to kill you if you do certain types of manoeuvers. You will learn how to takeoff and land by maintaining proper rotation and approach speeds. You will also learn how to navigate using either a magnetic compass or a gyro compass, just like they did in the 1940’s. You can also do high-altitude bombing with the real bombsight and autopilot controls if you like more advanced stuff. And if you think this stuff is too hard to learn, have no fear. There will ALWAYS be someone to explain these things to you if you ask for help. How do I know? Well, simply because I gave up on this game three times before Team Fusion finally modded the game and I asked for help on the ATAG forums (more on that later). These guys taught me everything I know and it is my pleasure to train new guys on a regular basis.Cliffs of Dover wouldn’t be where it is today if it wasn’t for the efforts of Team Fusion, but I must also mention something else about CloD. There is a sense of fellowship in its online community that is unique and has no equal anywhere else. ATAG, also known as the Air Tactical Assault Group, is an online community where it all started. ATAG hosts the most popular online server and their forums are THE place to go if you want to learn how to play this game. There is a virtual Flight School where people request lessons with volunteer teachers. People can join Virtual Squadrons, discuss History, create multiplayer events, online campaigns, and have lots of fun on Teamspeak (which is a must if you want to fly online and coordinate with your fellow pilots). Whether you are a flight sim veteran or someone who has never even seen an aircraft, there is always place for you among the skies of Dover. If you like competition, you will find in multiplayer some of the finest virtual pilots with thousands of hours under their belt. If you want to learn how to fly from scratch, you will find someone to teach you the basics, from how to start your engine and get your butt off the ground to advanced techniques on how to shoot down enemy planes in flames. Guaranteed.Overall, Cliffs of Dover is now living up to its promises and it is a real blast to fly. There is nothing more intense in the history of gaming than trying to shake that Messerschmitt off your six o’ clock. The next Team Fusion patch will include (for free) a new theater, new flyable planes (among them the mighty Wellington bomber) and all sorts of new goodies.And If you don’t believe me, here are some videos of the game in action.The Killer Angels

												TL:DR: With Team Fusion patches, this title still beats newer sims in terms of multiplayer experience. It's cheaper now too so a win win for all. Forget the BoS/BoM as your first title.  Go with IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover as your first entry into the genre and you'll likely never look back.Team Fusion are set to release their 5th patch in the coming months which opens up a new theatre and expands the airframe set.  IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover has a bright future and really is the #1 choice for anyone looking a full immersive experience. Full review:It is October 2016 as I write this review. For the record, this game came out in 2011  March 22nd. I've over 675hrs in game, much of that flying with a virtual Sqn.I am writing this review now because I can but also to highlight that this title is still the 'go-to' title for WW2 Warbird flight sim enthusiasts.In short, this ugly duckling has grown into a relatively elegant swan (I know, ducks and swans are two different biological lines .... but take that up with Hans Christian Andersen  ....)The ugly duckling part: This is well written and reviewed and I am not going to go over old cold coals other than to say that the then developer of IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover released a flight sim that was beautiful, full of promise and quite badly failed the performance test when released. It was full of ugly bugs, ran terribly and was soon consigned to the 'what a load of rubbish ... and it could have been so awesome' bin. The grown into a relatively elegant swan part: Enter the Team Fusion mod group. Mod groups do their thing and take released titles and polish them up. They often are responsible for taking titles what had been set to 'end of life support' status by the original developer and keep them supported. There are plenty of cases also of Mod group essentially taking over from defunct developers such as Falcon 4 by MicroProse and Richard Burns Rally by Warthog Games. Both these developers are no more yet their titles live on being developed even to this day.Team Fusion are the effective custodians of  IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover's continued development. The developer, C1 Company, to be fair, did make a final last ditch effort to iron out the show-stopper bugs before they abandoned the project. They succeeded in that effort and thereby can be credited with a base game that is today ... playable.However, the salute goes to Team Fusion, for taking this almost but not quite product and dragging it kicking and screaming through 4 patches of development into what I will describe as the shining star of multiplayer WW2 warbird flight simulators today. The name "IL-2 Sturmovik" can be found today in other titles. Sadly, these title do not, in my opinion, represent positive forward evolution of the genre.  IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover with Team Fusion still reigns supreme if a truly immersive flight simming multiplayer experience is what you are looking to achieve. There are a number of servers still running with two servers standing out. ATAG, basically a dog-fighter server, known for it's association with Team Fusion, (Team Fusion needed a virtual home and ATAG server, an independent entity provided that ) is a server that new folks and returned players regularly go to for fast turn PvP experiences.  http://theairtacticalassaultgroup.com/ACG is a long time realism server group which are regular stopping in places for the more experienced CLoD flight simmer. With missions and campaigns from time to time and large multiplayer sessions, ACG youtube videos are famous and beautiful. http://www.aircombatgroup.co.uk/server/clod.phpThe last server of note is Storm of War.  SoW replays the BoB campaign. Every reply is unique in many respects. Presently in SoW Season 4, it is the goto server for the more experienced sim pilot which is seeking a multiplayer campaign experience. This is particularly true if you have a group of friends you like to fly with. SoW has developed it's own statistical system which provides Sqn level statistics as well as individual sortie reports even and  accommodates groups of players with their own dedicated operating bases, custom airfield configurations, managed airframe stocks, real life TOPHAT in fighter command... the list goes one. http://www.stormofwar.org/So 5 years ago, no one could have imaged that in 2016, IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover would still represent the top of the pile of WW2 Warbird flight sim experiences. Newer titles, some even with "IL-2 Sturmovik" in their names (e.g. BoS & BoM) fail to match what IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover brings to the table today. In terms of multiplayer, BoS / Bom are not yet as successful.If asked, my recommendation could not be easier or clearer. Forget any reservations about CLoD being 5 years old title ... it really isn't that old due to Team Fusion patch updates. Enjoy the fact that you will save money and have a superior product (assuming you install the team fusion patches!)S!

												IL-2 CloD is a great realistic WW2 combat flight sim, and i really recommend it!It had a bad reputation at the start, because few reasons: it wasn’t ready when it was released, there wasn't really a manual (just a general information manual), off course it had to fight the original IL-2 series, which had much more planes/maps, which is natural situation with new series. and personally, but maybe more peoples also had a similar problem with CloD as me with the performance of the sim, my laptop and Desktop PC i had then, was not powerful enough to run it, and it was completely unplayable. (only 2 years after it came out i could play it with the PC i have today).Because all of those reasons the public opinion was very negative for this sim, and i assume the sales impacted by that, so, eventually, while the developers worked on the second sim in this new series, the company shut this series down and we left with only the first module. but, IMO, they had to give it a chance, it’s take time for peoples move to a new sim.After few years they started the current IL-2 Series(BoS), which is, btw, also great.So, CloD isn't continuing developed officially, but! fortunately, a modding team called "Team Fusion" continuing to develop this great sim. they already improved the sim very much, and they're still improving the sim, and will add new planes, sounds etc..in the future. so, if you are interested in this sim, those mods are a must. And today, thx to the community, we have many guides and manuals.About the sim itself, IL-2 CloD focus on the Battle of Britain theater, in a very detailed way, the map of the channel is large and pretty. the visuals are good and realistic.for a first sim in a series, there are plenty of flyable planes, fighters and bombers.The physics are good, much more detailed and realistic than the original IL-2 Series. you have the feeling of real flying, you can still fly with missing a major part of the wings, aerodynamic forces are modeled very nice, spins and all what we expected from this kind of sims.The damage model is also very detailed, the modeling of the construction of the plane is very in depth, the resolution of the hits is great. also, fire model is great, in which, a fire can start at one point in the skin of the plane and it spreads slowly to other areas in the skin of the plane. the systems damage model is also very detailed, almost every sub system can be damaged by many reasons.The systems of the planes are modeled very nice, and it’s a clickable cockpit with the mouse. There are a very few minor systems that are not modelled, for instance, the battery which is always on and you cannot control it, but the most systems are modeled, and in a great detail! The plane feels real, the gauges are shaking, the ADI is losing calibration by maneuvers, you can turn on and off the gunsight, you can change the range/target size of the gunsight etc..engine management is great, you can over revving the engine and the engine will damage, off course there is an over heat, under heat etc..The configuration of the weapons and ammo is very detailed, you can choose which guns to put in the planes, convergence, which ammo belts, and even make your personal ammo belts.There are many players online, for instance ATAG server is very popular. there is some minor graphic downsides, such as the animation of the controls of the planes which aren't smooth, and the mirrors dosen't work, but, those not so a big deal IMO, and i think that working mirrors are on the roadmap of Team Fusion.For summary, a great WW2 combat flying sim. IMO, this with DCS and the new IL-2 series are complete each other, and are the best sims for realistic WW2 combat flying sims.

When a game is made widely available on Steam, from a huge publisher as Ubisoft, I should not be expected to need to manually edit a bunch of .config and .ini text files buried deep within the installation directories just to get it to run! Yes, there is apparently a strong user community whom have created mods and patches to make this a much more playable game, but, again, a full-release paid-for title on Steam should not require any of this. There are early-access and pre-alpha release games that perform and play much more reliably than this. If you're willing to spend hours scraping online forums for user mods, configuration editing instructions and fooling with text-file jibberish, then perhaps you might find some enjoyment with this game. However, you shouldn't have to jump through those hoops, and this game shouldn't even be for sale on Steam. Remember, you can't get a refund.

												First let me say that I LOVE IL-2 Sturmovik and IL-Sturmovik Pacific and 1946.  They are great games and insofar as I can tell, not being a pilot myself very accurate flight sims. Alas, IL-2 Cliffs of Dover is not up to their previous efforts. It feels like they got bored halfway through development and never really finished. There is only one campaign (British) and it is lamentably short. The German side is just a series of missions.  There are no promotions, medals, et hoc genus omne as there were in the earlier games. Also missing (at least I can't find it) is the small HUD display that gave you airspeed, direction and altitude when you were in cockpit view. Accurate though the instrument panel may be, trying to read it in flight without spending two hours memorizing the layout first is . . . inconvenient.  The flight sim enthusiast who is truly dedicated (for which read 'crazed') can be expected to do this. I just want a quick indicator of airspeed and so on while still in cockpit view. Also missing is the time skip control so it's necessary to put the plane on autopilot and advance speed or else fly an actual two hour mission in real time. See comment about flight sim enthusiast above.  The trouble is when you run into the enemy when the speed is at 16x normal things can get a bit hairy . . .The quick mission builder is also nowhere near as good as previous versions where you could select almost any plane and a variety of maps and situations. In this one there are set scenarios and as far as I can tell you can't really adjust them. There is a full mission builder, but I never messed with that in the old games and I'm not touching it now as it was pretty complicated.  When I just wanted to shoot things down, the quick mission builder worked fine, when I wanted complicated, I started a career.Honestly compells me to admit that I actually bought this game two or three years ago, only to find my computer's graphics wasn't up to running it. So I've really only played it for the last week or so.Do I recommend it?  Yes. it's still a good flight sim if you buy it cheap. But it could -and should-have been so much better . . .

I cut my teeth on Il-2 1946 which is a great game in its own right, but never at any time whilst playing 1946 did I EVER get the feeling that CloD provides.  From having my heart pound through my chest as I sneak up on somone, hoping they don't spot me, to flying formation with 2 or 3 other guys looking for trouble; the total appreciation for what these lads went through in reality becomes apparent very quickly.  Luckily, you get to come back from the dead, but if you can stay alive long enough to learn the same aerial combat lessons they did, you might just stand a chance yet. The community is also great.  Jump on TeamSpeak or post in the ATAG forums and ask questions.  No matter how simple or basic they may seem, someone is always willing to help.  This is plainly, as immersive as it gets.  Wonderful game. 10/10

SummaryThe original game was abyssmal, but the TF-community patch a couple of years later made it at least playable. However, it is still really flawed and is showing its age. For a few specific things it is okay, but in general I'd recommend against it.Full reviewIL-2 Cliffs of Dover (CloD) was a disaster when it was released with many serious bugs. An independent group (Team Fusion, TF) created a series of patches, the latest of which makes the game quite playable. It is to their credit that they could salvage so much given the flaws. This reviews assumes that the latest TF patch (Version v4.312) has been installed. I should also point out that I am reviewing this from the perspective of a bomber pilot - my aircraft of choice in this sim is the Ju 88 A-1, so my comments are specific to that. I have over 1000 hours flying time, most of which is on the multiplayer servers (the single-player campaigns are hopeless).CloD implements a handful of human-flyable aircraft (Hurricane, Spitfire, Blenheim, Tiger Moth, Bf 109, Bf 110, He 111, G.50, Br20M, Ju 87 and Ju 88). Some of these (especially the fighters) have several variants. For the most part, the graphics are nice and the basic mechanisms work. The flight models seem okay to me (although I'm not a real-life pilot, so my opinion counts little here). However, there are some issues. In the case of the Ju 88, which is the aircraft that I have the most experience, it is riddled with problems. For example: faulty bomb drop sequences, nodding in mode-22, incorrect cockpit lights, no side-slip on Lotfe, only partially implemented radio/navigation systems, non-rotating C-stand turret ring, no ATA-limits on manifolds, unable to look around to see the levers on the left-side of the pilot, limited view from C-stand position, no navigation lights, no landing lights, no MG-reload animation, MG-continual-firing sound bug, indicator lamps incorrectly wired up, fuel-♥♥♥♥♥ not working correctly, no dive-brake indicator, ILS not working in multiplayer... to name but a few. All these seriously detract from the sim and make it deeply frustrating at times. Furthermore, the last patch nerfed the gunners, making bombers even more susceptible to fighters and, thus, even more frustrating to fly.On the other hand, the graphics are good, the map is moderately large and there is a good selection of targets, AI aircraft, ground vehicles, etc. to enhance the environment. The damage models are good and the implementations (particularly of the matched first-rate fighters) is supposedly very good.Unfortunately, the last patch was mid-2014 and there are no further patches planned. TF are supposedly working on new material, but this will be for a completely different theatre, rather than the Battle of Britain. Although the TF patch is very good, it also encrypts the game, thus locking out other modding teams. As a result community effort, excluding TF itself, has been snuffed out, which is a pity. There are few historical servers left these days (ACG being the only one I am aware of, now that SoW has shut down), and the single-player campaigns are effectively non-existent for bombers. Furthermore, there are a lot of broken features in the game, preventing mission-builders from harnessing the full power of the simulator.In conclusion, given the starting point of CloD, through the work of TF, it has become the best Battle of Britain simulator about. I have certainly flown a lot of hours on this sim. However, it shows its age and it has become a developmental dead end. Unless you are specifically interested in the Battle of Britain, it would be best to consider other titles. Thus, on balance I'd recommend against this one.

												IL-2 Sturmovik: Cliffs of Dover is one amazing game, with lots of fantastic stuff and some not so fantastic things. But let's start with the good stuff. Each plane has a completely realistic cockpit, almost exactly as you would see in real life.The outsides of the planes are also realistically modeled. Sitting in your cockpit, you can see the shadows of the clouds on the ground, on your wing, even in your cockpit. Lighting and and effects look fantastic. But by far the part I find most fun is the damage. Each part of the plane can become damaged or destroyed, with different levels of damage. As you fly your HE111 on a raid over the city of Dover, enemy Spitfires will attacks. They'll come in from behind you can let you have it. Bullets hit your fuel tanks, causing leaks. Bullets hit your pneumatics, causing you to loose the ability to use landing gear. Bullets hit on of your elevators, and causes it to detach from your plane. A few rounds hit your oil lines, causing you to loose visibility as oil covers the windshield and eventually causes your engines to stop. Every part is damageable. Engines, windshields, turrets, landing gear, flaps, wings, wing-tips. Fire can start and tear apart your plane over time. But this is all the fun part. I find the most fun thing to do is set up a mission that pits you, flying a bomber with a few wingmen, against tons of enemy fighters. Then, when they damage you, you try to limp back home, or crash land, or bail out. It is very entertaining skimming along the surface of a field as one of your engines is on fire and your landing gear isn't down. The props. can hit the ground and break. You could also crash land in water, but then you can't zoom out and admire your nice landing. There are numerous planes to fly, mostly fighters, unfortunately, but there are a few bombers. But that's where one of the not so fantasitc things come in. It would be so much fun piloting some giant 4-engine German FW200, but you can't. Most of the cool planes are reserved for AI only. There is a mod that allows you to fly these, but it should have been included in the first place. Another rather negative thing is that this game is extreamly graphic intensive. You need a very good card to play it without lag. I have a good computer, so this isn't a problem, but big rating companies, such as IGN, took points off for being so graphic intensive. The British campaign is wierd, with some missions begin fun, and others, not at all. In one mission you attack a flight of German bombers, which is fun. Then there is missions where you get transfered from one base to another, and all you do is fly. No combat. The last mission was just plain stupid. Instead of having some amazing finish with tons of explosions or something else interesting, all you do is fly an airplane with the character's girlfriend on his lap. It was pointless. I couldn't resist going to a high altitude and nose diving into the ground. But the final thing to mension is that this game is a simulator, which means there are things you don't do in an arcade style game. Before you take off, you manage your planes fuel mixture, open the radiators, pull back the flaps, turn on the brakes, and then turn the engine on. And then you still don't take off, you wait for clearance to take off. While in the air, the plane is in control. You can manage everything from trim to the heater. Being a simulator, you will also often find yourself doing nothing. You often need to fly for a bit before you find the enemy. There is an auto-pilot feature which can help fix, but it's your choise. So basically, if simulators aren't your thing, this game may be a risk for you, but note you can change almost all the realism settings, so that your get waypoints; you don't need to to mess with fuel mixture, trim, ect; you can turn off stalls, spins, blackouts, and redouts; you can even make your plane invincible. So in the end, this game can work for anyone. Just make sure you have a joystick, as the plane can't fly with the mouse, only a joystick or the arrow keys. My score: 8/10.

												OK. You bought the game and followed the updates. Now get the Team Fusion Mod and patch it with that. I have Win10 64Bit, and it works fine. Ok having said that. It's not an easy game, it's very hard.  Once you learn to start the various aircraft, and get them in the air, then you have to learn sharply about what your aircraft will and won't do. They spin if you look at them the wrong way. They get shot down. They fall in holes at the aerodrome and crack up. Then you want to take off. It's pure fluke if at first you manage it...practice makes perfect. Oh, and then there's landing the crates. That is a real task....that takes time and practice to learn and get down. The English and French countryside is gorgeous. The aircraft are a treat, so realistic. For a sim you pay less than $50 for it's remarkable how good it is. Of course you can wait and get it when it's on special. You get to fly Spitfires. Did I mention that the game has Spitfires? Oh yes, it has Spitfires. There are several flyable craft, from fighters on both sides to bombers. And then there's the player communities. Great bunch. You can interact with them by in-game chat or voiced with Teamspeak. There are websites you can visit. There are squadrons you can join, or jastas if you want to play for the German side. So all in all, while the learning curve is damn steep. Kinda like a church spire steep, it's worth it.

												I bought this game when it first came out in 2011, played it thorougly through and have returned to it occasionally since. Let me start with a frank but fair summary; if you're a fan of the IL-2 franchise or simply looking for a suit up and fly yet realistic flight simulator, then this is not your cup of tea! Windows 10 users will need to get a series of 3rd party mods to even start the game!If you want a complex and somewhat demanding, realistic flight simulator with a WW2 setting and are prepared to spend some time on optimizing and training. Then by all means, give it a go.My initial reaction back in 2011 was that it felt old, a bit like mid or late 90s combat sims. Slow, somewhat blocky or even cartoony graphics and optimized for the past generation of hardware. Which it probably is! Definetly unfinished. It has since improved some, not least in terms of performace (like a much needed multi core compability). Which is a bit of a shame since it actually has a lot going for it like the beatiful interior modeling, the lighting and the weather simulation. Exterior models unfortunately look a bit flat. As do the effects. Terrain varies from "rather nice" to "something a bit 2003". Flight models are fine. With a good joystick the flight experience become really enjoyable.The user interface is still one of the things that could scare people away. It is downright terrible! And confusing, escpecially in the mission menues. Here's where the 90s feeling really shows and not in a good way, I wouldn't be suprised if it was actually designed 10-12 years ago for a low budget strategy game and simply shoehorned in because they didn't have time to make a new one.Another issue is that there's isn't really much to do in the game except for casually flying around, unless you want to spend a lot of time in the mission builder (which is a heritage from the Il-2 and Su-27 sims of the early 2000s) or engage in multiplayer matches. The latter can be rather fun though if you end up in the right crowd. There is a short, linear and amusingly poorly written single player campaign. I won't even comment on the translation errors!Quick missions come in heaps and can be pretty fun once you get the hang of the game, but thanks to the clunky interface they are a bit frustrating to setup and the actual missions aren't very exiting.So would I recommend the game? Uhhhmm. For the hardcore flight simmer that has to own every sim on the market, it's a decent if a bit frustrating WW2 era simulator. It doesn't make up for the abstinence left by the original Il-2 series. But it has it's moments and there's still a small, yet thriving community around it.For the casual simmer or people without a special interest or experience with complex flight simulators, especially W10 users. Save your money! While there are plenty of decent arcade aviation games and modern, working, flights sims of all eras to go around. This isn't one of them.
